message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: TouringMachines: an architecture for dynamic, rational, mobile agents
Paper Abstract: It is becoming widely accepted that neither purely reactive nor purely deliberative control techniques are capable of producing the range of behaviours required of intelligent computational or robotic agents in dynamic, unpredictable, multi-agent worlds. We present a new architecture for controlling autonomous, mobile agents – building on previous work addressing reactive and deliberative control methods. The proposed multi-layered control architecture allows a resource-bounded, goal-directed agent to react promptly to unexpected changes in its environment; at the same time it enables the agent to reason predictively about potential conflicts by constructing and projecting causal models or theories which hypothesise other agents’ goals and intentions. The line of research adopted is very much a pragmatic one. A single, common architecture has been implemented which, being extensively parametrized, allows an experimenter to study functionally- and behaviourally-diverse agent configurations. A principal aim of this research is to understand the role different functional capabilities play in constraining an agent’s behaviour under varying environmental conditions. To this end, we have constructed an experimental testbed comprising a simulated multi-agent world in which a variety of agent configurations and behaviours have been investigated. Experience with the new control architecture is described.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of multi-agent systems:

## Definition and Core Concept

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Key Characteristics

Agents in multi-agent systems are at least partially independent and autonomous, with no agent designated as controlling. These systems can manifest self-organization, self-direction, and other complex behaviors even when individual agent strategies are simple.

## Composition and Types of Agents

Multi-agent systems research typically refers to software agents, though the agents could equally well be robots, humans, or human teams. Agents can vary from simple passive agents to complex, goal-driven systems.

## Applications

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance, and social structure modelling.(no content)With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

## Communication and Coordination

When agents can share knowledge using any agreed language within the constraints of the system's communication protocol, the approach may lead to common improvement. Example languages include Knowledge Query Manipulation Language (KQML) or Agent Communication Language (ACL).


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of multi-agent systems:

## Definition and Core Concept

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Key Characteristics

Agents in multi-agent systems are at least partially independent and autonomous, with no agent designated as controlling. These systems can manifest self-organization, self-direction, and other complex behaviors even when individual agent strategies are simple.

## Composition and Types of Agents

Multi-agent systems research typically refers to software agents, though the agents could equally well be robots, humans, or human teams. Agents can vary from simple passive agents to complex, goal-driven systems.

## Applications

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance, and social structure modelling.(no content)With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

## Communication and Coordination

When agents can share knowledge using any agreed language within the constraints of the system's communication protocol, the approach may lead to common improvement. Example languages include Knowledge Query Manipulation Language (KQML) or Agent Communication Language (ACL).

I've completed a web search for "mobile robots." Here's what I found:

## Overview of Mobile Robots

A mobile robot is an automatic machine that is capable of locomotion.(no content)Mobile robots have the capability to move around in their environment and are not fixed to one physical location.(no content)Mobile robotics is usually considered to be a subfield of robotics and information engineering.

## Components

The components of a mobile robot are a controller, sensors, actuators and power system.(no content)The controller is generally a microprocessor, embedded microcontroller or a personal computer (PC).

## Applications

Mobile robots are used in diverse settings:
- Hospitals have been using autonomous mobile robots to move materials for many years, and warehouses have installed mobile robotic systems to efficiently move materials from stocking shelves to order fulfillment zones.
- Mobile robots are also found in industrial, military and security settings.
- Mobile robots are also a major focus of current research and almost every major university has one or more labs that focus on mobile robot research.

## Notable Examples

Some historic and modern examples include Shakey the Robot, which was the first general-purpose mobile robot able to reason about its own actions, and more recently, autonomous vacuum cleaners and delivery robots.

Based on the search results, here's information about **deliberative control**:

## Main Concepts

The term "deliberative control" appears across several domains:

### Robotics
In robotics, the hierarchical or deliberative paradigm describes a top-down control structure in which the robot's actions are driven by explicit planning.(no content)The robot follows a sense-plan-act sequence, collecting sensory information, updating an internal model of the world and determining the next action based on the model.

### AI and Software Agents
A deliberative agent is a sort of software agent used mainly in multi-agent system simulations, defined as "one that possesses an explicitly represented, symbolic model of the world, and in which decisions (for example about what actions to perform) are made via symbolic reasoning".(no content)Compared to reactive agents, a deliberative agent's internal processes are more complex—the deliberative agent maintains a symbolic representation of the world it inhabits and possesses internal image of the external environment thus capable to plan its actions.

### General Concept
More broadly, deliberative control involves thoughtful planning and reasoning rather than reactive responses. This contrasts with reactive approaches that respond immediately to stimuli without explicit internal planning models.

Would you like more specific information about deliberative control in a particular domain?

Web search results for query: "reactive control"

Links: [{"title":"Voltage control and reactive power management - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voltage_control_and_reactive_power_management"},{"title":"Reaction control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reaction_control_system"},{"title":"Unified power flow controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unified_power_flow_controller"},{"title":"Ancillary services - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancillary_services_(electric_power)"},{"title":"Occupant-centric building controls - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Occupant-centric_building_controls"},{"title":"Reactive programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reactive_programming"},{"title":"Subsumption architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subsumption_architecture"},{"title":"Robotic paradigm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotic_paradigm"},{"title":"Behavior-based robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavior-based_robotics"},{"title":"Static VAR compensator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reactive_Power_Control_Relay"}]

Based on the web search results, "reactive control" has several different meanings depending on the context:

## Electrical Engineering

In electrical systems, reactive power control and voltage control are two facets of an ancillary service that enables reliability of transmission networks and facilitates the electricity market on these networks.(no content)These services generally include active power control or frequency control and reactive power control or voltage control, on various timescales.

## Building Control

Reactive control uses the real-time occupant preference and presents feedback to immediately alter the conditions of the space.(no content)This approach is useful for controlling systems with fast response times such as lighting systems, though reactive control is not ideal for systems with slow response times such as HVAC.

## Robotics

The reactive paradigm describes a bottom-up control structure in which the robot's actions emerge from direct interactions between the robots sensors and behaviours, without relying on a central plan or world model.(no content)Most behavior-based systems are also reactive, which means they need no programming of what specific objects look like. Instead, all the information is gleaned from the input of the robot's sensors, and the robot uses that information to gradually correct its actions according to changes in the immediate environment.

The common thread across these applications is that reactive control responds directly and immediately to current conditions or inputs rather than following a predetermined plan.

The reactive paradigm describes a bottom-up control structure in which the robot's actions emerge from direct interactions between the robots sensors and behaviours, without relying on a central plan or world model.(no content)Most behavior-based systems are also reactive, which means they need no programming of what specific objects look like. Instead, all the information is gleaned from the input of the robot's sensors, and the robot uses that information to gradually correct its actions according to changes in the immediate environment.

The common thread across these applications is that reactive control responds directly and immediately to current conditions or inputs rather than following a predetermined plan.

Here's what I found about causal models:

## Definition and Overview

In metaphysics and statistics, a causal model (also called a structural causal model) is a conceptual model that represents the causal mechanisms of a system.(no content)Causal models often employ formal causal notation, such as structural equation modeling or causal directed acyclic graphs (DAGs), to describe relationships among variables and to guide inference.

## Key Applications and Benefits

By clarifying which variables should be included, excluded, or controlled for, causal models can improve the design of empirical studies and the interpretation of results. They can also enable researchers to answer some causal questions using observational data, reducing the need for interventional studies such as randomized controlled trials.(no content)Causal models have found applications in signal processing, epidemiology, machine learning, cultural studies, and urbanism, and they can describe both linear and nonlinear processes.

## Types of Causal Models

Several important approaches include:

- **Causal Graphs**: In statistics, econometrics, epidemiology, genetics and related disciplines, causal graphs (also known as path diagrams, causal Bayesian networks or DAGs) are probabilistic graphical models used to encode assumptions about the data-generating process.

- **Structural Equation Modeling**: SEM involves a model representing how various aspects of some phenomenon are thought to causally connect to one another. Structural equation models often contain postulated causal connections among some latent variables (variables thought to exist but which can't be directly observed). Additional causal connections link those latent variables to observed variables whose values appear in a data set.

- **Rubin Causal Model**: The Rubin causal model (RCM), also known as the Neyman–Rubin causal model, is an approach to the statistical analysis of cause and effect based on the framework of potential outcomes, named after Donald Rubin.

Links: [{"title":"Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Agents_and_Multi-Agent_Systems"},{"title":"Autonomous agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_agent"},{"title":"International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Autonomous_Agents_and_Multiagent_Systems"},{"title":"Intelligent agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent"},{"title":"Autonomous agency theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_agency_theory"},{"title":"Software agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_agent"},{"title":"Automated negotiation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_negotiation"},{"title":"AutoGPT - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AutoGPT"},{"title":"Manus (AI agent) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manus_(AI_agent)"},{"title":"Cooperative distributed problem solving - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperative_distributed_problem_solving"}]

Here are the search results for "autonomous agents":

## Definition and Overview

Autonomous agents are computational systems that inhabit some complex dynamic environment, sense and act autonomously in this environment, and by doing so realize a set of goals or tasks for which they are designed. More specifically, an autonomous agent is a system situated within and a part of an environment that senses that environment and acts on it, over time, in pursuit of its own agenda and so as to effect what it senses in the future.

## Types of Agents

In the context of artificial intelligence, AI agents (also referred to as compound AI systems) are a class of intelligent agents distinguished by their ability to operate autonomously in complex environments.(no content)Agentic AI (also known as an AI agent or simply agent), expands this concept by proactively pursuing goals, making decisions, and taking actions over extended periods.(no content)In computer science, a software agent is a computer program that acts for a user or another program in a relationship of agency.(no content)Autonomous agents are capable of modifying the methods of achieving their objectives.

## Key Attributes

Agentic AI tools prioritize decision-making over content creation and do not require human prompts or continuous oversight. They possess several key attributes, including complex goal structures, natural language interfaces, the capacity to act independently of user supervision, and the integration of software tools or planning systems.

## Recent Examples

AutoGPT is an open-source autonomous software agent that uses OpenAI's large language models, such as GPT-4, to attempt to achieve a goal specified by a user in natural language. Unlike chatbots that require continuous user commands, AutoGPT works autonomously by breaking the main goal into smaller sub-tasks and using tools like web browsing and file management to complete them.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about subsumption architecture:

## Overview

Subsumption architecture is a control architecture that was proposed in opposition to traditional symbolic AI.(no content)Instead of guiding behavior by symbolic mental representations of the world, subsumption architecture couples sensory information to action selection in an intimate and bottom-up fashion.

## How It Works

A robot's lowest layer could be "avoid an object". The second layer would be "wander around", which runs beneath the third layer "explore the world". Because a robot must have the ability to "avoid objects" in order to "wander around" effectively, the subsumption architecture creates a system in which the higher layers utilize the lower-level competencies.(no content)The layers, which all receive sensor-information, work in parallel and generate outputs. These outputs can be commands to actuators, or signals that suppress or inhibit other layers.

## Origins and Applications

Links: [{"title":"Behavior-based robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavior-based_robotics"},{"title":"Behavior tree (artificial intelligence, robotics and control) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavior_tree_(artificial_intelligence,_robotics_and_control)"},{"title":"Talk:Behavior-based robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Behavior-based_robotics"},{"title":"Subsumption architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subsumption_architecture"},{"title":"Behavior tree - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavior_tree"},{"title":"Situated approach (artificial intelligence) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Situated_approach_(artificial_intelligence)"},{"title":"Swarm robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_robotics"},{"title":"Outline of robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_robotics"},{"title":"Whegs - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Whegs"},{"title":"Swarm intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_intelligence"}]

Here are the search results for behavior-based robotics:

## Overview

Behavior-based robotics (BBR) or behavioral robotics is an approach in robotics that focuses on robots that are able to exhibit complex-appearing behaviors despite little internal variable state to model its immediate environment, mostly gradually correcting its actions via sensory-motor links.

## Key Principles

Rather than build world models, behavior-based robots simply react to their environment and problems within that environment. They draw upon internal knowledge learned from their past experiences combined with their basic behaviors to resolve problems.(no content)Behavior-based robotics sets itself apart from traditional artificial intelligence by using biological systems as a model.(no content)Most behavior-based systems are also reactive, which means they need no programming of what a chair looks like, or what kind of surface the robot is moving on. Instead, all the information is gleaned from the input of the robot's sensors. The robot uses that information to gradually correct its actions according to the changes in immediate environment.

## Historical Development

The school of behavior-based robots owes much to work undertaken in the 1980s at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology by Rodney Brooks, who with students and colleagues built a series of wheeled and legged robots utilizing the subsumption architecture.(no content)In the 1950s, W. Grey Walter, an English scientist with a background in neurological research, built a pair of vacuum tube-based robots that were exhibited at the 1951 Festival of Britain, and which have simple but effective behavior-based control systems.

## Applications and Impact

Behavior-based robotics is extremely popular in robotics and allows the successful creation of real-time dynamic systems that can run in complex environments. For example, it underlies the intelligence of the Sony Aibo and many RoboCup robot teams.

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Classification:** `contribution` - The paper proposes a new multi-layered control architecture for autonomous mobile agents.

**Identified Triples (5 total):**

1. **Autonomous agent** (concept) - `uses`
   - The core subject of the paper's control architecture

2. **Multi-agent system** (concept) - `uses`
   - The paper addresses behavior in multi-agent worlds with conflicting agents

3. **Behavior-based robotics** (method) - `uses`
   - The hybrid architecture builds on reactive control principles from behavior-based robotics

4. **Causal model** (method) - `proposes`
   - The architecture enables agents to construct and project causal models to reason about other agents' intentions

5. **Mobile robot** (concept) - `uses`
   - The paper specifically targets control of autonomous mobile agents

- Both required relation types present (uses and proposes)
